reviewText:
I played the game all the way to the end:
- lower the sound at the start of the game, otherwise a extremly high sound will really hurt your ears
- took 56min to complete
- boring...from start to end. nothing interesting happens that makes you so you want to keep playing
- super confusing for no reason

I gave it a chance but even for a free game it's a waste of time.

reviewText:
Man, I'm tired... so tired... So so tired of low-rez walking sims full of pretentious emo BS. Slow paced, pretending to be deep, or 'psychological'... full of fake 'mystery'... You know what's REALLY getting old? bloody walls full of eyeballs, especially when they LITERALLY MEAN NOTHING.

So, you think this game looks interesting? Might be worth your time? Hey, it's free right? Let me save you 90 minutes of your life.

This is a game about a breakup.

Not that you'll figure that OUT until the very last minute of the game. And I do mean minute.

This is one of those games that tells you absolutely nothing about what's going on until you click on something, then it dumps a bunch of text on you that ALSO means nothing. It will string you along with 'mystery' that doesn't actually lead anywhere. Literally. You enter a mysterious catacomb that literally goes nowhere. Your character acts like he's living in a house he's never been in before when it turns out it was the HOUSE HE GREW UP IN ALL ALONG!!11 There's a mysterious tall man that keeps reappearing and spouting surreal garbage that literally means nothing and then he literally goes WELL IT WAS FUN I WON'T BE SEEING YOU and disappears from the story from there on. and then it turns out you were a whiny emo guy the WHOLE TIME

If I could have set my own pace I would have finished this game in about 16 minutes, barring the unnavigable 'maze' and the obnoxious addition puzzle. instead I was bogged down by a slow walking speed and fixed text crawl which made one word sentences linger on my screen for a quarter of a minute each.

I'm not going to bother looking at the other ending. Presumably it has something to do with the character's relationship with his dad, which is another thing.

Dear 'indie dev' hipsters, we really don't care about your ex-girlfriends and your daddy issues. Make a game about a murder mystery! Make a game about a power plant accident! Make a game where you can freakin run and jump and shoot monsters, and isn't IT'S REALLY ABOUT THE ATOM BOMB or whatever. Also WE ARE SICK OF YOUR CRAPPY POETRY, we wouldn't want to read it in a book, why would we want to play a game with it?

As a person who actually HAS gone through a breakup which sent me into a severe depression, I couldn't relate to this story about a guy who went through a breakup which sent him into a severe depression. I was just annoyed by it. Annoyed by it and a thousand other boring stupid games exactly like it.

reviewText:
Nyctophilia is defined as the preference for the night or darkness. In this case its a 2D side scrolling psychological thriller where you jump between worlds at night through the use of a light bulb. That's if you can get immersed in the game, because to others it could be considered just a game where you're stuck in a house and every time you're out of the house its in a dark maze. Its a game about tediously looking for the next place and scouring everything you can before near dumb luck stumbles upon the solution.

The story begins with you trapped in a long dark room. Walking to the right reveals a wall and a sound behind you. Moving to the left leaves a mystery as the room is getting smaller. Soon after going back and forth your character awakens from a dream in his hotel room.

He's on some sort of journey that leads him to a stay at a vacant house. The house has two bathrooms and two bedrooms, a kitchen, a cellar, an attic, a balcony and a few other rooms. They're each small, but provide for some space for you to have a look around.

The 2D and psychological thriller work against one another. Think of it more as a low fidelity 2D point and click adventure without the clicking. The resolution is just a few pixels that leaves for little detail so the psychological part comes in the form of numerous text boxes that describe things, thoughts and feelings. Since its such a small locale that spans a house and little else, your character walks slow, but flailing his heels as he moves.

Each night you go to bed and that's when the game transforms between a blend of nightmare and memory. You'll find a light bulb that when used in the menu you hop between realms where you are yourself, but in a different clothes or a different era entirely. Here in this new dimension you have eyes looking at you. When you collect scattered diary pages, the eyes grow in size after you're done. Its a way of saying that you are being watched.

From time to time you'll meet a towering butler that explains things in cryptic ways. I would say he's the narrator, but he's more of a way to keep you on edge as to how strange things can get. Is the butler even real or just a hallucination brought on by strange discoveries?

With the darkness contrasting the daytime they do set two completely different moods, but they're still the same tone thanks to the game's piano music in the background. Its a simple loop with a sense of mystery and an effective way to keep you on edge.

One of the only facets to your character beyond having dreams that take him into another dimension is the fact that he refuses to do things. Is the attic locked? No. He says he doesn't want to go there and then adds he doesn't want to get there. It makes me think that he's too lazy to crawl up a ladder. There are other times he refuses to do things and his descriptions of things are his own thoughts that lead me to believe he's antisocial and prefers the isolation of the house.

There is a lot of darkness in the game with plenty of lights to flip on. You can still see in the dark and lights are never a requirement, so your character can read through books in a room with no light source. The character can even tell he's talking to a woman when I saw nothing. Perhaps that's his real Nyctophilia. He can see in the dark better than the game elaborates.

In some moments of extreme darkness there's a light emitting from your character so you the player can see. I would say there's a lighter guiding the way, but a lighter is never shown so I can assume its the light bulb in your pocket, but then again the light emits before you get the light bulb.

The game gives you tasks and lists them, which is great, but I had done the tasks before they were mandatory. When I was told to wash up, I was confused trying to use the downstairs bathroom. I then scoured the entire locale looking for the other bathroom. I checked the yard, a second bedroom and various other places until the last place I looked was the second bathroom with the soap. That's when I was told to have a look around the yard, the second bedroom and other rooms.

Its the wandering around and checking everything until I stumble upon the solution that takes me out of the game. Having to look all over the house for the wind that the game tells me is a sound. I could hear no sound. I checked everything several times even burdened with the character's slow movement. Until finally, I found what I was looking for and while everything is marked with an interaction button, this had no indicator. I had walked by it several times and even tried to do something with it long before I was ever supposed to. Therefore in my eyes it was just a part of the background.

Then there's the underground maze that you need to explore. This labyrinth is dark with black holes in the wall. Its a place so easy to get lost in that you'll get a map that lets you warp to the beginning again. The only problem is that after the labyrinth, using the map can cause the game to crash back to the desktop. At that point my mind just checked out of the game. We had a good run, got lost, frustrated and angry looking over a house. Now with a crash it symbolized that I should give up on the game, because it pads out its time with complex switch puzzles and dark mazes.

You'll find little in the way of settings, only two languages and its keyboard only. That's no issue since the game is so basic and requires left and right, X for interacting and tab for menu things.

There's a relaxing, calming mystery here for those that want down the rabbit hole bad enough to find it. For the rest of us, its a game with issues. Its a good start for a better game in time.

* Broken English is Hilarious [EDIT: AS OF OCTOBER 8th 2015 Tranlation as been Fixed" YAWN]

reviewText: Unfortunately, I keep running into an error on Day 3 (black screen) which prevents me from continuing the game further, so I can only give my impressions so far. I'm enjoying the game so far, mostly because it is presenting the main character very realistically as someone struggling with mental issues.  Choosing whether or not to let the protagonist forget to bathe, eat properly or take his medicine adds a lot of realism to the backdrop of the overall story. The biggest problem I can see so far, is that the English isn't written particularly well. Not that it's bad writing, I can just tell the developer's first language may not be English. If they ever happen to read this, I would be happy to offer myself as an English proofreader. Improving the grammar and writing might help the game reach more people.

I tried giving this game a chance. Really, I did. But this game is truly a masterpiece of it's own.

-For one, the English translation is incredibly bad. I know the person who made this didn't have English as a first language, but if the effort was put through to cater this to an English audience, at least take the time to have an English proofreader. Despite that though, the grammar errors are probably the most redeeming part of this entire game! No joke. Though it is meant to be a horror game, the broken translation, especially in the first bit of dialog is the most riveting conversation ever. So if you're looking for a laugh, then there you go.

reviewText:
Nyctophilia.  A very specific condition where a person enjoys seeing Topher Grace smothered in nectar....  which makes no sense at all,  which is also how I would sum up this game.

It's the very vague type of storytelling that makes the gamer hope for a shocking revelation to make the time worthwhile. But that doesn't happen.  The graphic are 8 bit. That's fine.  The music is simple, cheap and moody.  That's fine too.  There is a mind boggling catacomb to wade through and another lever puzzle that's somewhat interesting.  But is this not a story game to begin with? Either I didn't pay enough attention or the story just didn't go anywhere.

In the end, what Nyctophilia is probably trying to say is, Why are you still awake deep into the night.  Go to bed!""

reviewText:
Imagine waking up, not entirely sure where you are, but knowing it's not quite where you're supposed to be. Nyctophilia runs somewhere along those lines, but it's not entirely clear whether you should be where you end up, either.  A tale of parallel lives and mental mysteries, this game provides a bit to chew on mentally despite its rather short play time.

In Nyctophilia, you assume the role of a young man who doesn't entirely want to return to the game's primary setting, a house from his past, but who seems to have little choice in the matter. Over a series of days, you explore the house and what was left in it, including shadows of the past that grow increasingly menacing. At the same time, you explore the main character's past, only to find why the game's called Nyctophilia in the first place.

As a caveat, I need to point out that I played this game back when the English translation was rather rough, and things were a bit buggy; I had a game-ending issue about 1/3 of the way through and had to replay the first day or so. Even then, I enjoyed what was presented, getting enough out of the translation to sort of know what was going on, and probably wondering more about the rest than I would have with a straight translation. There was enough weirdness going on to creep me out, though the sudden shift in location and direction toward the end threw me off a bit. I'm eager to give it another go with the updated translation sometime soon so I can figure the rest out.

The game itself is rather short, taking maybe an hour or so to finish, but it's still not bad for free. I particularly enjoyed some of the quips your character makes upon inspecting things around the house; these change each day, so be sure to try interacting with everything. I also liked some of the more trivial-seeming options, such as what drink to start the day with. Personally, I'm a kegs and eggs kind of guy, and I'm glad that was available (and I didn't run out).

So yeah, it's a bit rough around the edges, but it's free and it's only an hour. Give it a chance.

reviewText: wanna spend your time figuring out puzzles that lead no where? this is the game.

Glitched on Day 3 and I can no longer play it. I've tried uninstalling it and redownloading it all kinds of ways, but it always freezes up at the same spot. Apparently I'm not the only person who has these issues and so I can't really recommend this game. I read the other reviews and it doesn't look like I'm missing much, but still I'd like to be able to actually play the game myself and make my own decision. Would I recommend what I did play so far? Not really unfortunately.

Sadly I can't recommend this game. It definitely had some good aspects, but other games present them better.
It had too many flaws while playing.

First some positive things: I really liked the background music and the graphics. The walking animation of our protagonist could have been done a bit better. It looks a bit strange and if you walk very slowly or just tap a bit on the keyboard then the guy doesn't really walk but kinda floats over the ground. But that's just some small aspect, otherwise these points were done well.

Now to the aspects that were negative in my point of view:
In general the game was very slow-paced. TOO slow. The walking speed was too slow, the story could have been told faster and the section with the catacombs were annoying and slow.
Then the thing with the eyes on the walls... That is just overused now and here it doesn't even have any meaning. It ain't creative. Well, and the story... Definitely was 'weird' as the summary promises. But there are too many questions left open and it's too confusing. To be honest I won't play it again to see 'the other side of the story'.
The english is okay, there are still some mistakes but I can live with them. It's not that bad.

The end was actually good, as it tells you how you can reach the other end. It makes you want to play the game again. Well, it COULD if the game overall would have been done better in those aspects I mentoined. As it is now, I doubt many will play it again just to see the other side of the story.
Honestly, just a horrible game overall. Just don't get it. I got it because I said oh all these bad reviews

reviewText: This may not be the best game on the market, but for its price it's definitely worth trying!\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jnkFHYNz2EE\nThis game would have much better reviews if the English version had better grammar. I mean, it really feels like the developer simply threw his Russian dialogue into google translate, and pasted that into the game. However, if you just pretend that the main character in the game is actually a Russian immigrant who actually speaks that way with a strong accent, this game becomes much more enjoyable! I actually liked the retro pixel graphics, and thought the idea being the game was good. It could definitely use a lot of refining, but considering the game is free, I definitely don't feel like I wasted my time playing it, and did enjoy it. I suggest you give it a shot!

reviewText:
Okay so. This game was fun, very fun. I played it in roughly...2 hours at most.
The only annoying thing about this game are two things. First is the grammar. The fellow who made this had a few grammarical issues and I had to translate the sentences sometimes when I was reading them out loud myself.
Although I don't care much for grammar really, there has to be some understandablitiy.
The second thing was the maze like crypt. It's very confusing and I got lost for a good while trying to find everything.
I would recommend some sort of hint system for that area so people don't have to wonder as much as I did.
Other than that, I loved this game and would recommend it to anyone who desired to play it.

reviewText: Where to begin with this one? To start, the design of the game is Pixelated. Not a bad thing, as many pixel based games can be great. You start in a nightmare where the walls close in on you, and wake up in a hotel. You leave to a house, which is not really explained why you went there. You decide after JUST leaving the hotel, you need another nap!\nThis game is badly structured. The goals are terrible and lack any information. Examining things will reveal very little. The written script for this game is terrible (No offence to the creator, as English clearly is not their first language) but for future reference, a translator could be of assistance. Often times, reading a sentence just won't make much sense. The story is a jumbled mess to me, as I had no clue what was going on. Overall, the game lets itself down with lack of information, or clues as to why you are here, what are you doing, ect.

5.2 hours ( I forgot the game on ) it doesnt take that long to do it all. I would say about an hour. 2 hours if you are persistent enough to do it twice to see both endings.

I had a feeling I wouldn't enjoy this game because of the name, the person who made this game most likely heard this word one time then obsessed over it and tried to make this seem dark and creepy.  This game is not creepy/scary what it is is very slow paced, low res, horrid game.  The walking speed was enough to make me want to quit, but I tried to finish it.  Then I spent all of day two looking in rooms (that I had already walked slowly to once already) then went right back to sleep which was very lame. Day 3 I spent about 15 minutes walking the catacombs losing my mind because it takes forever to walk anywhere (Can you tell I hate the walking speed?)  Then a tall man told me two things one being to go places I've already been because they most likely changed and that people are not always who they seem to be ...  Yea I've never heard that in a game before. I gave up on day 4 because I just don't care.

Nyctophilia is a very good game to play. I really love the guitar background music and the puzzles in it. The story is really great. However, it is a pretty small story. i try to guess if the main character is alive but i failed. I think the tall man is his dad, but i have no proof. The ending is a kind of vague to me. Anyway the story of nyctophilia is very throught provoking and i really recommand this game to quiet and patient players.

This game is very good! I recommend it for people who love horror but dislike the fact that they are freaked out afterwards!\nAlthough the ending is a bit weird you'll most of the storyline. Tip: when in house look at tasks so you don't aimlessly wander around.
Bad mechanics, bad choice of keys, bad walking animation, slow gameplay and much much more. Wouldnt recommend it
Works as good as sleeping pill.

It's not ultimately that bad but it gets tedious and because of that I can't recommend it.

What prevents Nyctophilia from getting a recommended score is the fact that the core of the game gets tedious.  Much of the text doesn't allow the player to skip past it so it plays out in a very slow, drawn-out way with little in the way of interaction.

I've only played through it once, and that's mainly because the core of the game is dull and I stopped caring.  The puzzles in the game aren't very hard and are there mostly to just slow one down instead of being interesting.  The game wants to be Silent Hill and it wants to be Lone Survivor but those games have a great deal of interactivity that this one lacks.

It shows a lot of promise but much of the imagery is cliché, and the protagonist is flat.  The music is definitely trying to emmulate SIlent Hill and there's nothing wrong with that as it's done pretty well, but it's wasted on the game because it lacks any real tension.

Also the walking animation is ridiculous.  I know walking is difficult to animate but even I know to move more than one leg at a time.

Improving the game will require the following:
- Allow the player to advance text and skip cutscenes.
- Add tension.  Threats.  Something.  Even Close Your Eyes" understood this.
- Be less obvious.  The opening is spoiled because the protagonist yells out that the walls are closing instead of having me realize it on my own."
This is a fun game with a great soundtrack if you like indies and can get over the broken english you should give it a try.

I will say, the game definitely had me interested... then I played it. Personally, it's just not the kind of game that fits me.

+Nice, dark theme
+Music had good work put into it
-Slow Controls
-Horrid grammar (understandable due to Russian developer)
-Confusing plot (not in a good way)
-CAN'T SPEED THROUGH DIALOGUE

Honestly, you could very well end up liking this game. I just don't like it myself.
Stupidest free game ever invented it's like a picture book!\n10/10 would rate this again
boring

Don't play that game. It lasts exactly 119mn if you waste time exploring every single room (which is useless) including the minutes you keep staring at the credits because you just didn't understand/don't want to believe it actually ended. At the beginning , you think it's a psychological game about a guy driven in madness and wait for some exciting scary things to happen. But it's just about some guy getting sentimental. I'm so disappointed.\nThe soundtrack is pretty cool, thought !

The walking animation just made me want to cry.

It could potentially turn into something good, but a large overhaul would be needed in my opinion.

The sound track was also well-developed, except for the unholy screeching at the beginning of the game that filled my eardrums with blood for a solid minute. I wasn't even in the game yet, and I already wanted to quit because of this hellspawn trying to voraciously ravage my ear canal. Please turn your volume down before playing.

What prevents Nyctophilia from getting a recommended score is the fact that the core of the game gets tedious.  Much of the text doesn't allow the player to skip past it so it plays out in a very slow, drawn-out way with little in the way of interaction.

I've only played through it once, and that's mainly because the core of the game is dull and I stopped caring.  The puzzles in the game aren't very hard and are there mostly to just slow one down instead of being interesting.  The game wants to be Silent Hill and it wants to be Lone Survivor but those games have a great deal of interactivity that this one lacks.

It shows a lot of promise but much of the imagery is cliché, and the protagonist is flat.  The music is definitely trying to emmulate SIlent Hill and there's nothing wrong with that as it's done pretty well, but it's wasted on the game because it lacks any real tension.

Also the walking animation is ridiculous.  I know walking is difficult to animate but even I know to move more than one leg at a time.

- Allow the player to advance text and skip cutscenes.

yes, unlike all the other butt hurt folk. i would actually recommend this game! it has a great soundtrack, mysterious ways and an overall creepy vibe. the art is great, the contorls are simplistic and.. and!! what the hell is going on?! haha, it was a slightly confusing story and a little short but! a great game to say the least.

I really wanted to like this - it's got pixel graphics in a style I like, a simple and easy-to-use interface & controls, and nice music/sound. But it was just too boring.

You play a man recovering from some kind of illness who's moved to a house alone as part of your recuperation plan. In this house your job is to explore daily, things that may lead to your recovery.

I managed to last till Day 2 (or was it 3) before complete tedium took over. Tasks are so completely mundane and uninteresting (e.g. take bath, read letter, go out onto balcony, etc), and there just isn't any motivation to continue playing. What the game lacks is some excitement, and a good reason to move forward.
Boring
great game, but yeah, a bit TOO short, wish is was longer, because i really wanted to know everythinf that was happening with the house and the catacombs,
